title: Shift Happens: A book about keyboards

last_post.content:
Shift Happens launches tomorrow on Kickstarter, 9 am PST – get notified via the pre-launch project page: https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/mwichary/shift-happens?ref=2h744m See also: https://shifthappens.site

What is?
• An authoritative exploration of keyboards from typewriters to the current day, spanning 150 years
• 1,216-page, two-volume book in a slipcover
• Over 1,300 photos
• Written by @mwichary
• Edited by yours truly
• Every computer keyboard you love? Almost certainly in there. Every typewriter you desire? Also present.

title: Bring back personal blogging

last_post.content:
"The biggest reason personal blogs need to make a comeback is a simple one: we should all be in control of our own platforms.

If what is happening on Twitter hasn’t demonstrated it, our relationship with these social media platforms is tenuous at best. The thing we are using to build our popularity today could very well be destroyed and disappear from the internet tomorrow, and then what?

What happens to all the content you have created?"

https://www.theverge.com/23513418/bring-back-personal-blogging

The core proposition is clear from the UI: everyone gets less say except for Google.

title: Global North and Global South - Wikipedia

last_post.content:
We're organizing a free Bayesian Data Analysis course targeted for Global south (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_North_and_Global_South) and other underrepresented groups. This is currently the third rendition of the BDA GSU course. See more information and the link to the registration form at https://avehtari.github.io/BDA_course_Aalto/gsu2023.html

The course is based on BDA3 book and BDA course at
Aalto. All course material is freely available.

#Bayes #MCMC #Stan

title: Find the human art behind the A.I. images

last_post.content:
The problem with this https://www.stableattribution.com/ (allowing lookup of which artists contributed to a generated image) is it works because Stability (and MidJourney and Hugging Faces diffusion algo) are built on an open source underlying dataset LAION.
Meanwhile those who put their stuff behind closed source / trade secret wall (hello OpenAI, sic) are not open to analysis.

LaMDA is rebranded as Bard. A non-full-sized version is to be released in the next few weeks

title: Open Syllabus: Explorer

last_post.content: @quinnanya @miriamkp @scott_bot @bc_butler @zoeleblanc @andrewpiper @ryancordell Quinn brings up a feature of Viral Text that I think is paradigmatic of many projects that decide that the output of text- and data-mining in the humanities should not be (exclusively) a screenshot Figure B on a traditional paper. Once you turn this kind of work interactive online, then it doubles as a "discovery mechanism" to use the language of library science: Half new knowledge, half service. You could also call it a para-text like @sramsay does in _An Algorithmic Cricitism_. In short, any and all projects that do this can be used as examples. "Viral Texts" is a great one. I use "Open Syllabus Explorer and Galaxy" myself to make this point. Mostly because I was a PI back in the day. https://opensyllabus.org/

title: Open Review of the Second Half of “After Disruption: A Future for Cultural Memory”

last_post.content:
Starting on revisions to respond to peer reviews of my forthcoming book, After Disruption: A Future for Cultural Memory. For background on the book, you can read the full drafts of it here http://www.trevorowens.org/2022/07/open-review-of-the-second-half-of-after-disruption-a-future-for-cultural-memory/ and here http://www.trevorowens.org/2022/01/open-review-of-the-first-half-of-after-disruption-a-future-for-cultural-memory/

I am planning to add some additional targeted positive examples of cultural memory work/projects/initiatives that model centering an ethic of care, a maintenance mindset, and a focus on repair.

title: MIT study finds huge carbon cost to self-driving cars

last_post.content:
And this is why the solutions to #GlobalWarming and #UrbanPlanning will never be "better cars".

"The study found that with a mass global takeup of autonomous vehicles, the powerful onboard computers needed to run them could generate as many greenhouse gas emissions as all the data centres in operation today. [0.3 per cent of global emissions]"

title: London wants to eradicate homelessness. Here's how Finland is doing it | CBC News

last_post.content:
“The thing we understand, which is proven in international research, is that providing housing for homeless persons is always more cost-effective for society than keeping people homeless…We did a study that showed when a former homeless person gets housing, even with support, the cost savings for society are at least €15,000/person per year.”

Canadian city learning from Finland.
https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/london/london-wants-to-eradicate-homelessness-here-s-how-finland-is-doing-it-1.6728398

title: Elon Musk says bots with ‘good content’ can use Twitter’s API for free

last_post.content:
Does Twitter’s free tier for the Twitter API affect our dropping Twitter support from NetNewsWire?

https://www.theverge.com/2023/2/5/23586577/elon-musk-bots-good-content-twitters-api-free

It does not. The big reason is that that free tier is write-only — and NetNewsWire is a reading app.

But even if they did make another change and allow for some free use for readers, we could never rely on it. Twitter has proven that it’s an unacceptable partner.

title: Why I Don't Care if Students Use GPT

last_post.content:
I've been spending a lot of time thinking about #ChatGPT and academic assessment and why I am not so concerned about it (at the college level). It's not that ChatGPT is bad for education. It's that our education system is built upon a basis wherein we do assessment wrong.

What @hoffman writes in his blog below comes close to how I think of things (thanks for saving me a lot of time writing my thoughts down!)

http://write.guyhoffman.com/why-i-dont-care-if-students-use-gpt

title: Talking About Large Language Models

last_post.content:
We moeten het hebben over hoe we we het hebben over #AI.

"The more adept LLMs become at mimicking human language, the more vulnerable we become to anthropomorphism, to seeing the systems in which they are embedded as more human like than they really are. This trend is amplified by the natural tendency to use philosophically loaded terms, such as "knows", "believes", and "thinks", when describing these systems."

Great paper by @mshanahan

➡https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.03551

"The stock photography company is accusing Stability AI of “brazen infringement of Getty Images’ intellectual property on a staggering scale.” It claims that Stability AI copied more than 12 million images from its database “without permission ... or compensation ... as part of its efforts to build a competing business,” and that the startup has infringed on both the company’s #copyright and #trademark protections."

title: Cards for Ukraine

last_post.content:
Since donations are drying up, figured I mention our little project one more time.

https://cards-for-ukraine.at

We convert donations to €50 food vouchers for Ukrainian families who fled to Austria. We operate zero overhead, and even have a discount contract with a large local grocery chain.

I just finished packaging 260 cards of the last batch. We've sent out about €180.000 worth of vouchers since May 2022.

We're also 100% transparent. All contracts/orders/payments here:
https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1PxOL8A44bIRU1Hdoq87_2iXSLNmnMXQr

title: Making SQLite extensions pip install-able

last_post.content:
Ferociously useful work here from @alexgarciaxyz: https://observablehq.com/@asg017/making-sqlite-extensions-pip-install-able

Alex figured out how to bundle compiled SQLite extensions in per-platform Python wheels and ship them to PyPI - so now you can do things like "pip install sqlite-regex" to get his SQLite regex functions, which he implemented in Rust

More notes here: https://simonwillison.net/2023/Feb/6/making-sqlite-extensions-pip-install-able/

Among the services we will host:

* Mastodon
* Pixelfed
* Calckey
* Lemmy
* Gitea

title: Data Explorer: Environmental Impacts of Food

last_post.content:
One for breakfast: Greenhouse gas emissions per kilogram of different milks.

The production of cow’s milk causes the highest emissions – oat milk the lowest.

From our ‘Environmental Impacts of Food Explorer’
https://ourworldindata.org/explorers/food-footprints?facet=none&uniformYAxis=0&Commodity+or+Specific+Food+Product=Specific+food+products&Environmental+Impact=Carbon+footprint&Kilogram+%2F+Protein+%2F+Calories=Per+kilogram&By+stage+of+supply+chain=false&country=Beefburger~Cow%27s+milk~Pizza~Oat+milk~Soy+milk~Almond+milk~Rice+milk

title: How Duolingo’s AI Learns What You Need to Learn

last_post.content:
I write a fair bit about the things at AI/ML is not good at, so I want to acknowledge some of the really amazing use cases.

One seems to be in very specific kinds of education.

I'm very impressed with the capabilities of Duolingo, which I've been using 10-15 hours a week for the past four months.

Here's an interesting article from the Duolingo team about how they use ML to make it such a good learning experience.

https://spectrum.ieee.org/duolingo
